info.long_name: Access to day care by capacity
info.short_description: Count of day care capacity (seats) based on provider locations
info.long_description: Count of day care capacity (seats) based on provider locations. Address and capacity data were collected from Virginia Department of Social Services day care search tool.
info.statement: There are {value} daycare seats in {features.name}.

info.long_name: Day care geographic availability (3-step floating catchment area)
info.short_description: Index of day care availability based on supply of and demand for providers
info.long_description: Day care availability based on 3-step floating catchment areas. This method is an aggregation of day care facilities per population ratios weighted by distance or travel time in each catchment area (area within which a provider is accessible). Provider address data were collected from Virginia Department of Social Services day care search tool. The demand for day care services is the population 0-15 years old and the supply is the capacity of day cares (number of seats).
info.statement: The daycare availability for {features.name} is {value}.

info.long_name: 2-year schools per 100k people over 14
info.short_description: Number of 2-year schools per 100k people over 14.
info.long_description: Number of schools authorized to award Associates degrees or 2-year or longer certificates per 100k people over 14, based on 3-step floating catchment areas defined by distance. Catchment areas were calculated using (a) 2-year schools as listed by the National Center for Education Statistics, with supply values of 1, (b) Census block groups, with supply values as the population over the age of 14 as reported the American Community Survey 5-year summaries, and (c) distances between school locations and block group centroids, weighted by a Gaussian function with a scaling parameter set to 18, as calculated by the catchment R package.
info.statement: There are {value} 2-year schools per 100k people over 14 in {features.name}.

info.long_name: Digital Equity Index
info.short_description: Digital Equity Index captures the relative equity of digital access, with 0 being a score of relative equity and 100 being relative inequity.
info.long_description: The Digital Equity Index (DEI) is a composite variable indicating the degree of broadband equity as it relates to adoption, accessibility, and infrastructure. It ranges from 0 to 100, where 100 indicates the most equitable broadband access. The DEI is constructed at the Census tract level and is composed of the following variables: percent of the population under 65 years of age, percent of the population with at least a high school education, percent of the population with income below the poverty level, percent of the population without a disability, the ratio between the share of homes making $75,000 or more per year with internet and the share of homes making less than $35,000 per year without internet, percent of the population with at least one computer, percent of the population with internet access, percent of the population that is low income (less than 30% of HUD Area Median Family Income) and have a housing cost burden over 30%, and average download speeds, upload speeds, and latency from Ookla speed tests.
info.statement: The Digital Equity Index for {features.name} is {value}.

info.long_name: Dental care geographic availability (2 step-enhanced floating catchment areas)
info.short_description: Index of dental care availability based on supply and demand of providers
info.long_description: Dental care availability based on 2-step enhanced floating catchment areas. This method is an aggregation of dentists per population ratios weighted by distance or travel time in each catchment area (area within which a provider is accessible). Weights are defined for the demand for dentists (population served by dentists). Provider address data were collected from WebMD's online Physician Directory.
info.statement: The dental care availability for {features.name} is {value}.

info.long_name: Percentage of food insecure children
info.short_description: Food insecure children are those children living in households experiencing food insecurity (a lack of access to enough food for an active, healthy life).
info.long_description: Food insecurity refers to USDA's measure of lack of access, at times, to enough food for an active, healthy life for all household members and limited or uncertain availability of nutritionally adequate foods. Food insecurity refers to USDA's measure of lack of access, at times, to enough food for an active, healthy life for all household members and limited or uncertain availability of nutritionally adequate foods. Food insecure children are those children living in households experiencing food insecurity. Food-insecure households are not necessarily food insecure all the time. Food insecurity may reflect a household's need to make trade-offs between important basic needs, such as housing or medical bills, and purchasing nutritionally adequate foods.
info.statement: {value} of the population of children in {features.name} are food insecure.

info.long_name: Average meal cost ($)
info.short_description: The average weekly dollar amount food-secure individuals report spending on food.
info.long_description: The average weekly dollar amount food-secure individuals report spending on food, as estimated by the Current Population Survey, divided by 21 (assuming three meals a day, seven days a week). This amount has been adjusted to reflect local food prices and relevant taxes.
info.statement: The average meal cost in {features.name} is {value}.

Catchment areas were calculated using (a) 2-year schools as listed by the National Center for Education Statistics, with supply values of 1, (b) Census block groups, with supply values as the population over the age of 14 as reported the American Community Survey 5-year summaries, and (c) distances between school locations and block group centroids, weighted by a Gaussian function with a scaling parameter set to 18, as calculated by the catchment R package.

info.long_name: Digital Equity Index
info.short_description: Digital Equity Index captures the relative equity of digital access, with 0 being a score of relative equity and 100 being relative inequity.
info.long_description: The Digital Equity Index (DEI) is a composite variable indicating the degree of broadband equity as it relates to adoption, accessibility, and infrastructure. It ranges from 0 to 100, where 100 indicates the most equitable broadband access. The DEI is constructed at the Census tract level and is composed of the following variables: percent of the population under 65 years of age, percent of the population with at least a high school education, percent of the population with income below the poverty level, percent of the population without a disability, the ratio between the share of homes making $75,000 or more per year with internet and the share of homes making less than $35,000 per year without internet, percent of the population with at least one computer, percent of the population with internet access, percent of the population that is low income (less than 30% of HUD Area Median Family Income) and have a housing cost burden over 30%, and average download speeds, upload speeds, and latency from Ookla speed tests.
info.statement: The Digital Equity Index for {features.name} is {value}.

info.long_name: Percentage of food insecure children
info.short_description: Food insecure children are those children living in households experiencing food insecurity (a lack of access to enough food for an active, healthy life).
info.long_description: Food insecurity refers to USDA's measure of lack of access, at times, to enough food for an active, healthy life for all household members and limited or uncertain availability of nutritionally adequate foods. Food insecurity refers to USDA's measure of lack of access, at times, to enough food for an active, healthy life for all household members and limited or uncertain availability of nutritionally adequate foods. Food insecure children are those children living in households experiencing food insecurity. Food-insecure households are not necessarily food insecure all the time. Food insecurity may reflect a household's need to make trade-offs between important basic needs, such as housing or medical bills, and purchasing nutritionally adequate foods.
info.statement: {value} of the population of children in {features.name} are food insecure.

info.long_name: Average meal cost ($)
info.short_description: The average weekly dollar amount food-secure individuals report spending on food.
info.long_description: The average weekly dollar amount food-secure individuals report spending on food, as estimated by the Current Population Survey, divided by 21 (assuming three meals a day, seven days a week). This amount has been adjusted to reflect local food prices and relevant taxes.
info.statement: The average meal cost in {features.name} is {value}.

info.long_name: Percentage of food insecure
info.short_description: Food insecurity refers to USDA's measure of lack of access, at times, to enough food for an active, healthy life for all household members and limited or uncertain availability of nutritionally adequate foods.
info.long_description: Food insecurity refers to USDA's measure of lack of access, at times, to enough food for an active, healthy life for all household members and limited or uncertain availability of nutritionally adequate foods. Food-insecure households are not necessarily food insecure all the time. Food insecurity may reflect a household's need to make trade-offs between important basic needs, such as housing or medical bills, and purchasing nutritionally adequate foods.

info.long_name: Count of food insecure children
info.short_description: Food insecure children are those children living in households experiencing food insecurity (a lack of access to enough food for an active, healthy life).
info.long_description: Food insecurity refers to USDA's measure of lack of access, at times, to enough food for an active, healthy life for all household members and limited or uncertain availability of nutritionally adequate foods. Food insecurity refers to USDA's measure of lack of access, at times, to enough food for an active, healthy life for all household members and limited or uncertain availability of nutritionally adequate foods. Food insecure children are those children living in households experiencing food insecurity. Food-insecure households are not necessarily food insecure all the time. Food insecurity may reflect a household's need to make trade-offs between important basic needs, such as housing or medical bills, and purchasing nutritionally adequate foods.
info.statement: The population of food insecure children in {features.name} is {value}.

info.long_name: Day care geographic availability (3-step floating catchment area)
info.short_description: Index of day care availability based on supply of and demand for providers
info.long_description: Day care availability based on 3-step floating catchment areas. This method is an aggregation of day care facilities per population ratios weighted by distance or travel time in each catchment area (area within which a provider is accessible). Provider address data were collected from Virginia Department of Social Services day care search tool. The demand for day care services is the population 0-15 years old and the supply is the capacity of day cares (number of seats).
info.statement: The daycare availability for {features.name} is {value}.

info.long_name: 2-year schools per 100k people over 14
info.short_description: Number of 2-year schools per 100k people over 14.
info.long_description: Number of schools authorized to award Associates degrees or 2-year or longer certificates per 100k people over 14, based on 3-step floating catchment areas defined by distance. Catchment areas were calculated using (a) 2-year schools as listed by the National Center for Education Statistics, with supply values of 1, (b) Census block groups, with supply values as the population over the age of 14 as reported the American Community Survey 5-year summaries, and (c) distances between school locations and block group centroids, weighted by a Gaussian function with a scaling parameter set to 18, as calculated by the catchment R package.
info.statement: There are {value} 2-year schools per 100k people over 14 in {features.name}.

sources.name: National Center for Education Statistics
sources.location: Integrated Postsecondary Education Data System, Institutional Characteristics

info.long_name: drive time to nearest 2-year school
info.short_description: Drive time to the nearest 2-year schools.
info.long_description: Minimal drive time to a school authorized to award Associates degrees or 2-year or longer certificates from the Census block group centroid, as calculated by the Open Source Routing Machine in 2022. School locations are from the National Center for Education Statistics. All distances are calculated at the block group level, then averaged up to higher-level geographies.
info.statement: It takes {value} to drive to a 2-year school from {features.name}'s block group centroids on average.

sources.name: National Center for Education Statistics
sources.location: Integrated Postsecondary Education Data System, Institutional Characteristics

info.long_name: <2-year schools per 100k people over 14
info.short_description: Number of <2-year schools per 100k people over 14, calculated within floating catchment areas.
info.long_description: Number of schools authorized to award certificates that are typically obtained in less than 2 years per 100k people over 14, based on 3-step floating catchment areas defined by distance. Catchment areas were calculated using (a) <2-year schools as listed by the National Center for Education Statistics, with supply values of 1, (b) Census block groups, with supply values as the population over the age of 14 as reported the American Community Survey 5-year summaries, and (c) distances between school locations and block group centroids, weighted by a Gaussian function with a scaling parameter set to 18, as calculated by the catchment R package.
info.statement: There are {value} <2-year schools per 100k people over 14 in {features.name}.

info.long_name: Digital Equity Index
info.short_description: Digital Equity Index captures the relative equity of digital access, with 0 being a score of relative equity and 100 being relative inequity.
info.long_description: The Digital Equity Index (DEI) is a composite variable indicating the degree of broadband equity as it relates to adoption, accessibility, and infrastructure. It ranges from 0 to 100, where 100 indicates the most equitable broadband access. The DEI is constructed at the Census tract level and is composed of the following variables: percent of the population under 65 years of age, percent of the population with at least a high school education, percent of the population with income below the poverty level, percent of the population without a disability, the ratio between the share of homes making $75,000 or more per year with internet and the share of homes making less than $35,000 per year without internet, percent of the population with at least one computer, percent of the population with internet access, percent of the population that is low income (less than 30% of HUD Area Median Family Income) and have a housing cost burden over 30%, and average download speeds, upload speeds, and latency from Ookla speed tests.
info.statement: The Digital Equity Index for {features.name} is {value}.

info.long_name: Dental care geographic availability (2 step-enhanced floating catchment areas)
info.short_description: Index of dental care availability based on supply and demand of providers
info.long_description: Dental care availability based on 2-step enhanced floating catchment areas. This method is an aggregation of dentists per population ratios weighted by distance or travel time in each catchment area (area within which a provider is accessible). Weights are defined for the demand for dentists (population served by dentists). Provider address data were collected from WebMD's online Physician Directory.
info.statement: The dental care availability for {features.name} is {value}.

info.long_name: Percentage of food insecure children
info.short_description: Food insecure children are those children living in households experiencing food insecurity (a lack of access to enough food for an active, healthy life).
info.long_description: Food insecurity refers to USDA's measure of lack of access, at times, to enough food for an active, healthy life for all household members and limited or uncertain availability of nutritionally adequate foods. Food insecurity refers to USDA's measure of lack of access, at times, to enough food for an active, healthy life for all household members and limited or uncertain availability of nutritionally adequate foods. Food insecure children are those children living in households experiencing food insecurity. Food-insecure households are not necessarily food insecure all the time. Food insecurity may reflect a household's need to make trade-offs between important basic needs, such as housing or medical bills, and purchasing nutritionally adequate foods.
info.statement: {value} of the population of children in {features.name} are food insecure.

info.long_name: Average meal cost ($)
info.short_description: The average weekly dollar amount food-secure individuals report spending on food.
info.long_description: The average weekly dollar amount food-secure individuals report spending on food, as estimated by the Current Population Survey, divided by 21 (assuming three meals a day, seven days a week). This amount has been adjusted to reflect local food prices and relevant taxes.
info.statement: The average meal cost in {features.name} is {value}.

info.short_description: Number of 2-year schools per 100k people over 14.
info.long_description: Number of schools authorized to award Associates degrees or 2-year or longer certificates per 100k people over 14, based on 3-step floating catchment areas defined by distance. Catchment areas were calculated using (a) 2-year schools as listed by the National Center for Education Statistics, with supply values of 1, (b) Census block groups, with supply values as the population over the age of 14 as reported the American Community Survey 5-year summaries, and (c) distances between school locations and block group centroids, weighted by a Gaussian function with a scaling parameter set to 18, as calculated by the catchment R package.
info.statement: There are {value} 2-year schools per 100k people over 14 in {features.name}.

info.long_name: Digital Equity Index
info.short_description: Digital Equity Index captures the relative equity of digital access, with 0 being a score of relative equity and 100 being relative inequity.
info.long_description: The Digital Equity Index (DEI) is a composite variable indicating the degree of broadband equity as it relates to adoption, accessibility, and infrastructure. It ranges from 0 to 100, where 100 indicates the most equitable broadband access. The DEI is constructed at the Census tract level and is composed of the following variables: percent of the population under 65 years of age, percent of the population with at least a high school education, percent of the population with income below the poverty level, percent of the population without a disability, the ratio between the share of homes making $75,000 or more per year with internet and the share of homes making less than $35,000 per year without internet, percent of the population with at least one computer, percent of the population with internet access, percent of the population that is low income (less than 30% of HUD Area Median Family Income) and have a housing cost burden over 30%, and average download speeds, upload speeds, and latency from Ookla speed tests.
info.statement: The Digital Equity Index for {features.name} is {value}.

This method is an aggregation of dentists per population ratios weighted by distance or travel time in each catchment area (area within which a provider is accessible). Weights are defined for the demand for dentists (population served by dentists). Provider address data were collected from WebMD's online Physician Directory.
info.statement: The dental care availability for {features.name} is {value}.

info.long_name: Percentage of food insecure children
info.short_description: Food insecure children are those children living in households experiencing food insecurity (a lack of access to enough food for an active, healthy life).
info.long_description: Food insecurity refers to USDA's measure of lack of access, at times, to enough food for an active, healthy life for all household members and limited or uncertain availability of nutritionally adequate foods. Food insecurity refers to USDA's measure of lack of access, at times, to enough food for an active, healthy life for all household members and limited or uncertain availability of nutritionally adequate foods. Food insecure children are those children living in households experiencing food insecurity. Food-insecure households are not necessarily food insecure all the time. Food insecurity may reflect a household's need to make trade-offs between important basic needs, such as housing or medical bills, and purchasing nutritionally adequate foods.
info.statement: {value} of the population of children in {features.name} are food insecure.

info.long_name: Average meal cost ($)
info.short_description: The average weekly dollar amount food-secure individuals report spending on food.
info.long_description: The average weekly dollar amount food-secure individuals report spending on food, as estimated by the Current Population Survey, divided by 21 (assuming three meals a day, seven days a week). This amount has been adjusted to reflect local food prices and relevant taxes.
info.statement: The average meal cost in {features.name} is {value}.

info.long_name: Mental health services access score (3-step  floating catchment areas)
info.short_description: Index of mental health services accessibility based on supply and demand of facilities
info.long_description: Mental health services access score based on 3-step floating catchment areas. This method is an aggregation of facilities per population ratios weighted by distance or travel time in each catchment area (area within which a facility is accessible). Weights are defined for the demand for facilities (adult population).
info.statement: The mental health services accessibility score for {features.name} is {value}.

info.long_name: Access to day care by capacity
info.short_description: Count of day care capacity (seats) based on provider locations
info.long_description: Count of day care capacity (seats) based on provider locations. Address and capacity data were collected from Virginia Department of Social Services day care search tool.
info.statement: There are {value} daycare seats in {features.name}.

info.long_name: Day care geographic availability (3-step floating catchment area)
info.short_description: Index of day care availability based on supply of and demand for providers
info.long_description: Day care availability based on 3-step floating catchment areas. This method is an aggregation of day care facilities per population ratios weighted by distance or travel time in each catchment area (area within which a provider is accessible). Provider address data were collected from Virginia Department of Social Services day care search tool. The demand for day care services is the population 0-15 years old and the supply is the capacity of day cares (number of seats).
info.statement: The daycare availability for {features.name} is {value}.

info.long_name: 2-year schools per 100k people over 14
info.short_description: Number of 2-year schools per 100k people over 14.
info.long_description: Number of schools authorized to award Associates degrees or 2-year or longer certificates per 100k people over 14, based on 3-step floating catchment areas defined by distance. Catchment areas were calculated using (a) 2-year schools as listed by the National Center for Education Statistics, with supply values of 1, (b) Census block groups, with supply values as the population over the age of 14 as reported the American Community Survey 5-year summaries, and (c) distances between school locations and block group centroids, weighted by a Gaussian function with a scaling parameter set to 18, as calculated by the catchment R package.
info.statement: There are {value} 2-year schools per 100k people over 14 in {features.name}.

sources.name: National Center for Education Statistics
sources.location: Integrated Postsecondary Education Data System, Institutional Characteristics

sources.name: American Community Survey
sources.location: data/5_year_seq_by_state

info.long_name: drive time to nearest 2-year school
info.short_description: Drive time to the nearest 2-year schools.
info.long_description: Minimal drive time to a school authorized to award Associates degrees or 2-year or longer certificates from the Census block group centroid, as calculated by the Open Source Routing Machine in 2022. School locations are from the National Center for Education Statistics. All distances are calculated at the block group level, then averaged up to higher-level geographies.
info.statement: It takes {value} to drive to a 2-year school from {features.name}'s block group centroids on average.

sources.name: National Center for Education Statistics
sources.location: Integrated Postsecondary Education Data System, Institutional Characteristics

Catchment areas were calculated using (a) <2-year schools as listed by the National Center for Education Statistics, with supply values of 1, (b) Census block groups, with supply values as the population over the age of 14 as reported the American Community Survey 5-year summaries, and (c) distances between school locations and block group centroids, weighted by a Gaussian function with a scaling parameter set to 18, as calculated by the catchment R package.
info.statement: There are {value} <2-year schools per 100k people over 14 in {features.name}.

info.long_name: 2-year biomedical programs per 100k people over 14
info.short_description: Number of 2-year schools with biomedical programs per 100k people over 14, calculated within floating catchment areas.
info.long_description: Number of schools authorized to award Associates degrees or less than 2-year or longer certificates with biomedical programs (any with Classification of Institutional Programs [CIP] codes starting with 26) per 100k people over 14, based on 3-step floating catchment areas defined by distance. Catchment areas were calculated using (a) 2-year schools with any degrees conferred in the given year with a CIP code starting with 26, as listed by the National Center for Education Statistics, with supply values of 1, (b) Census block groups, with supply values as the population over the age of 14 as reported the American Community Survey 5-year summaries, and (c) distances between school locations and block group centroids, weighted by a Gaussian function with a scaling parameter set to 18, as calculated by the catchment R package.
info.statement: There are {value} 2-year schools with a biomedical program per 100k people over 14 in {features.name}.

info.long_name: Digital Equity Index
info.short_description: Digital Equity Index captures the relative equity of digital access, with 0 being a score of relative equity and 100 being relative inequity.
info.long_description: The Digital Equity Index (DEI) is a composite variable indicating the degree of broadband equity as it relates to adoption, accessibility, and infrastructure. It ranges from 0 to 100, where 100 indicates the most equitable broadband access. The DEI is constructed at the Census tract level and is composed of the following variables: percent of the population under 65 years of age, percent of the population with at least a high school education, percent of the population with income below the poverty level, percent of the population without a disability, the ratio between the share of homes making $75,000 or more per year with internet and the share of homes making less than $35,000 per year without internet, percent of the population with at least one computer, percent of the population with internet access, percent of the population that is low income (less than 30% of HUD Area Median Family Income) and have a housing cost burden over 30%, and average download speeds, upload speeds, and latency from Ookla speed tests.
info.statement: The Digital Equity Index for {features.name} is {value}.

info.long_name: Dental care geographic availability (2 step-enhanced floating catchment areas)
info.short_description: Index of dental care availability based on supply and demand of providers
info.long_description: Dental care availability based on 2-step enhanced floating catchment areas. This method is an aggregation of dentists per population ratios weighted by distance or travel time in each catchment area (area within which a provider is accessible). Weights are defined for the demand for dentists (population served by dentists). Provider address data were collected from WebMD's online Physician Directory.
info.statement: The dental care availability for {features.name} is {value}.

info.long_name: Percentage of food insecure children
info.short_description: Food insecure children are those children living in households experiencing food insecurity (a lack of access to enough food for an active, healthy life).
info.long_description: Food insecurity refers to USDA's measure of lack of access, at times, to enough food for an active, healthy life for all household members and limited or uncertain availability of nutritionally adequate foods. Food insecurity refers to USDA's measure of lack of access, at times, to enough food for an active, healthy life for all household members and limited or uncertain availability of nutritionally adequate foods. Food insecure children are those children living in households experiencing food insecurity. Food-insecure households are not necessarily food insecure all the time. Food insecurity may reflect a household's need to make trade-offs between important basic needs, such as housing or medical bills, and purchasing nutritionally adequate foods.
info.statement: {value} of the population of children in {features.name} are food insecure.

info.long_name: Average meal cost ($)
info.short_description: The average weekly dollar amount food-secure individuals report spending on food.
info.long_description: The average weekly dollar amount food-secure individuals report spending on food, as estimated by the Current Population Survey, divided by 21 (assuming three meals a day, seven days a week). This amount has been adjusted to reflect local food prices and relevant taxes.
info.statement: The average meal cost in {features.name} is {value}.

info.long_name: 2-year schools per 100k people over 14
info.short_description: Number of 2-year schools per 100k people over 14.
info.long_description: Number of schools authorized to award Associates degrees or 2-year or longer certificates per 100k people over 14, based on 3-step floating catchment areas defined by distance. Catchment areas were calculated using (a) 2-year schools as listed by the National Center for Education Statistics, with supply values of 1, (b) Census block groups, with supply values as the population over the age of 14 as reported the American Community Survey 5-year summaries, and (c) distances between school locations and block group centroids, weighted by a Gaussian function with a scaling parameter set to 18, as calculated by the catchment R package.
info.statement: There are {value} 2-year schools per 100k people over 14 in {features.name}.

info.long_name: Digital Equity Index
info.short_description: Digital Equity Index captures the relative equity of digital access, with 0 being a score of relative equity and 100 being relative inequity.
info.long_description: The Digital Equity Index (DEI) is a composite variable indicating the degree of broadband equity as it relates to adoption, accessibility, and infrastructure. It ranges from 0 to 100, where 100 indicates the most equitable broadband access. The DEI is constructed at the Census tract level and is composed of the following variables: percent of the population under 65 years of age, percent of the population with at least a high school education, percent of the population with income below the poverty level, percent of the population without a disability, the ratio between the share of homes making $75,000 or more per year with internet and the share of homes making less than $35,000 per year without internet, percent of the population with at least one computer, percent of the population with internet access, percent of the population that is low income (less than 30% of HUD Area Median Family Income) and have a housing cost burden over 30%, and average download speeds, upload speeds, and latency from Ookla speed tests.
info.statement: The Digital Equity Index for {features.name} is {value}.

Weights are defined for the demand for dentists (population served by dentists). Provider address data were collected from WebMD's online Physician Directory.
info.statement: The dental care availability for {features.name} is {value}.

info.long_name: Percentage of food insecure children
info.short_description: Food insecure children are those children living in households experiencing food insecurity (a lack of access to enough food for an active, healthy life).
info.long_description: Food insecurity refers to USDA's measure of lack of access, at times, to enough food for an active, healthy life for all household members and limited or uncertain availability of nutritionally adequate foods. Food insecurity refers to USDA's measure of lack of access, at times, to enough food for an active, healthy life for all household members and limited or uncertain availability of nutritionally adequate foods. Food insecure children are those children living in households experiencing food insecurity. Food-insecure households are not necessarily food insecure all the time. Food insecurity may reflect a household's need to make trade-offs between important basic needs, such as housing or medical bills, and purchasing nutritionally adequate foods.
info.statement: {value} of the population of children in {features.name} are food insecure.

info.long_name: Average meal cost ($)
info.short_description: The average weekly dollar amount food-secure individuals report spending on food.
info.long_description: The average weekly dollar amount food-secure individuals report spending on food, as estimated by the Current Population Survey, divided by 21 (assuming three meals a day, seven days a week). This amount has been adjusted to reflect local food prices and relevant taxes.
info.statement: The average meal cost in {features.name} is {value}.

info.long_name: Mental health services access score (3-step  floating catchment areas)
info.short_description: Index of mental health services accessibility based on supply and demand of facilities
info.long_description: Mental health services access score based on 3-step floating catchment areas. This method is an aggregation of facilities per population ratios weighted by distance or travel time in each catchment area (area within which a facility is accessible). Weights are defined for the demand for facilities (adult population).
info.statement: The mental health services accessibility score for {features.name} is {value}.

info.statement: There are {value} daycare seats in {features.name}.

info.long_name: Day care geographic availability (3-step floating catchment area)
info.short_description: Index of day care availability based on supply of and demand for providers
info.long_description: Day care availability based on 3-step floating catchment areas. This method is an aggregation of day care facilities per population ratios weighted by distance or travel time in each catchment area (area within which a provider is accessible). Provider address data were collected from Virginia Department of Social Services day care search tool. The demand for day care services is the population 0-15 years old and the supply is the capacity of day cares (number of seats).
info.statement: The daycare availability for {features.name} is {value}.

info.long_name: 2-year schools per 100k people over 14
info.short_description: Number of 2-year schools per 100k people over 14.
info.long_description: Number of schools authorized to award Associates degrees or 2-year or longer certificates per 100k people over 14, based on 3-step floating catchment areas defined by distance. Catchment areas were calculated using (a) 2-year schools as listed by the National Center for Education Statistics, with supply values of 1, (b) Census block groups, with supply values as the population over the age of 14 as reported the American Community Survey 5-year summaries, and (c) distances between school locations and block group centroids, weighted by a Gaussian function with a scaling parameter set to 18, as calculated by the catchment R package.
info.statement: There are {value} 2-year schools per 100k people over 14 in {features.name}.

sources.name: National Center for Education Statistics
sources.location: Integrated Postsecondary Education Data System, Institutional Characteristics

School locations are from the National Center for Education Statistics. All distances are calculated at the block group level, then averaged up to higher-level geographies.
info.statement: It takes {value} to drive to a 2-year school from {features.name}'s block group centroids on average.

Catchment areas were calculated using (a) 2-year schools with any degrees conferred in the given year with a CIP code starting with 11, as listed by the National Center for Education Statistics, with supply values of 1, (b) Census block groups, with supply values as the population over the age of 14 as reported the American Community Survey 5-year summaries, and (c) distances between school locations and block group centroids, weighted by a Gaussian function with a scaling parameter set to 18, as calculated by the catchment R package.
info.statement: There are {value} 2-year schools with a computer science program per 100k people over 14 in {features.name}.

info.long_name: Digital Equity Index
info.short_description: Digital Equity Index captures the relative equity of digital access, with 0 being a score of relative equity and 100 being relative inequity.
info.long_description: The Digital Equity Index (DEI) is a composite variable indicating the degree of broadband equity as it relates to adoption, accessibility, and infrastructure. It ranges from 0 to 100, where 100 indicates the most equitable broadband access. The DEI is constructed at the Census tract level and is composed of the following variables: percent of the population under 65 years of age, percent of the population with at least a high school education, percent of the population with income below the poverty level, percent of the population without a disability, the ratio between the share of homes making $75,000 or more per year with internet and the share of homes making less than $35,000 per year without internet, percent of the population with at least one computer, percent of the population with internet access, percent of the population that is low income (less than 30% of HUD Area Median Family Income) and have a housing cost burden over 30%, and average download speeds, upload speeds, and latency from Ookla speed tests.
info.statement: The Digital Equity Index for {features.name} is {value}.

info.long_name: Dental care geographic availability (2 step-enhanced floating catchment areas)
info.short_description: Index of dental care availability based on supply and demand of providers
info.long_description: Dental care availability based on 2-step enhanced floating catchment areas. This method is an aggregation of dentists per population ratios weighted by distance or travel time in each catchment area (area within which a provider is accessible). Weights are defined for the demand for dentists (population served by dentists). Provider address data were collected from WebMD's online Physician Directory.
info.statement: The dental care availability for {features.name} is {value}.

info.long_name: Percentage of food insecure children
info.short_description: Food insecure children are those children living in households experiencing food insecurity (a lack of access to enough food for an active, healthy life).
info.long_description: Food insecurity refers to USDA's measure of lack of access, at times, to enough food for an active, healthy life for all household members and limited or uncertain availability of nutritionally adequate foods. Food insecurity refers to USDA's measure of lack of access, at times, to enough food for an active, healthy life for all household members and limited or uncertain availability of nutritionally adequate foods. Food insecure children are those children living in households experiencing food insecurity. Food-insecure households are not necessarily food insecure all the time. Food insecurity may reflect a household's need to make trade-offs between important basic needs, such as housing or medical bills, and purchasing nutritionally adequate foods.
info.statement: {value} of the population of children in {features.name} are food insecure.

info.long_name: Average meal cost ($)
info.short_description: The average weekly dollar amount food-secure individuals report spending on food.
info.long_description: The average weekly dollar amount food-secure individuals report spending on food, as estimated by the Current Population Survey, divided by 21 (assuming three meals a day, seven days a week). This amount has been adjusted to reflect local food prices and relevant taxes.
info.statement: The average meal cost in {features.name} is {value}.

info.long_name: 2-year schools per 100k people over 14
info.short_description: Number of 2-year schools per 100k people over 14.
info.long_description: Number of schools authorized to award Associates degrees or 2-year or longer certificates per 100k people over 14, based on 3-step floating catchment areas defined by distance. Catchment areas were calculated using (a) 2-year schools as listed by the National Center for Education Statistics, with supply values of 1, (b) Census block groups, with supply values as the population over the age of 14 as reported the American Community Survey 5-year summaries, and (c) distances between school locations and block group centroids, weighted by a Gaussian function with a scaling parameter set to 18, as calculated by the catchment R package.
info.statement: There are {value} 2-year schools per 100k people over 14 in {features.name}.

info.long_name: Digital Equity Index
info.short_description: Digital Equity Index captures the relative equity of digital access, with 0 being a score of relative equity and 100 being relative inequity.
info.long_description: The Digital Equity Index (DEI) is a composite variable indicating the degree of broadband equity as it relates to adoption, accessibility, and infrastructure. It ranges from 0 to 100, where 100 indicates the most equitable broadband access. The DEI is constructed at the Census tract level and is composed of the following variables: percent of the population under 65 years of age, percent of the population with at least a high school education, percent of the population with income below the poverty level, percent of the population without a disability, the ratio between the share of homes making $75,000 or more per year with internet and the share of homes making less than $35,000 per year without internet, percent of the population with at least one computer, percent of the population with internet access, percent of the population that is low income (less than 30% of HUD Area Median Family Income) and have a housing cost burden over 30%, and average download speeds, upload speeds, and latency from Ookla speed tests.
info.statement: The Digital Equity Index for {features.name} is {value}.

info.long_name: Dental care geographic availability (2 step-enhanced floating catchment areas)
info.short_description: Index of dental care availability based on supply and demand of providers
info.long_description: Dental care availability based on 2-step enhanced floating catchment areas. This method is an aggregation of dentists per population ratios weighted by distance or travel time in each catchment area (area within which a provider is accessible). Weights are defined for the demand for dentists (population served by dentists). Provider address data were collected from WebMD's online Physician Directory.
info.statement: The dental care availability for {features.name} is {value}.

info.long_name: Percentage of food insecure children
info.short_description: Food insecure children are those children living in households experiencing food insecurity (a lack of access to enough food for an active, healthy life).
info.long_description: Food insecurity refers to USDA's measure of lack of access, at times, to enough food for an active, healthy life for all household members and limited or uncertain availability of nutritionally adequate foods. Food insecurity refers to USDA's measure of lack of access, at times, to enough food for an active, healthy life for all household members and limited or uncertain availability of nutritionally adequate foods. Food insecure children are those children living in households experiencing food insecurity. Food-insecure households are not necessarily food insecure all the time. Food insecurity may reflect a household's need to make trade-offs between important basic needs, such as housing or medical bills, and purchasing nutritionally adequate foods.
info.statement: {value} of the population of children in {features.name} are food insecure.

info.long_name: Average meal cost ($)
info.short_description: The average weekly dollar amount food-secure individuals report spending on food.
info.long_description: The average weekly dollar amount food-secure individuals report spending on food, as estimated by the Current Population Survey, divided by 21 (assuming three meals a day, seven days a week). This amount has been adjusted to reflect local food prices and relevant taxes.
info.statement: The average meal cost in {features.name} is {value}.

info.long_name: Mental health services access by median drive time to the ten closest facilities in minutes
info.short_description: Median drive time (minutes) to the ten closest mental health services facilities
info.long_description: Median drive time in minutes to the ten closest mental health services facilities. Facility location data was collected from the Homeland Infrastructure Foundation-Level Data (HIFLD) repository. Drive times were computed using Open Source Routing Machine (Using roads for year 2021).
info.statement: The median drive time to the ten closest mental health service facilities to {features.name} is {value}.

info.long_name: Mental health services access score (3-step  floating catchment areas)
info.short_description: Index of mental health services accessibility based on supply and demand of facilities
info.long_description: Mental health services access score based on 3-step floating catchment areas. This method is an aggregation of facilities per population ratios weighted by distance or travel time in each catchment area (area within which a facility is accessible). Weights are defined for the demand for facilities (adult population).
info.statement: The mental health services accessibility score for {features.name} is {value}.

info.long_name: Access to mental health services by count
info.short_description: Count of mental health facilities based on facility locations
info.long_description: Count of mental health facilities based on facility locations. Location data was collected from the Homeland Infrastructure Foundation-Level Data (HIFLD) repository.
info.statement: There are {value} mental health facilities in {features.name}.

info.long_name: Retail food environment index
info.short_description: The number of available healthy and less healthy food retailers. A higher score indicates more available healthy options per less healthy options. A score of 0 indicates available no options (food desert).
info.statement: The Retail food environment index is {value} in {features.name}.

info.long_name: Percentage of population with health insurance
info.short_description: Percentage of the population (ages 19-64) self-reported to be currently covered by any type of health insurance or health coverage plan
info.long_description: Percentage of the population self-reported to be currently covered by any type of health insurance or health coverage plan. Based on American Community Survey Table B27010 in ACS 2015/2019 5-year estimates.
info.statement: {value} of the population has health insurance in {features.name}.

info.long_name: Pediatric care geographic availability (2-step enhanced floating catchment areas)
info.short_description: Index of pediatric care physician availability based on supply and demand of providers
info.long_description: Pediatric care availability based on 2-step enhanced floating catchment areas. This method is an aggregation of pediatricians per population ratios weighted by distance or travel time in each catchment area (area within which a provider is accessible). Weights are defined for the demand for pediatricians (population under 16). Provider address data were collected from WebMD's online Physician Directory.
info.statement: The pediatric care availability for {features.name} is {value}.

info.statement: {value} of the hospitalizations in {features.name} were preventable (due to conditions usually treated in outpatient settings).

info.long_name: Primary care geographic availability (2-step enhanced floating catchment areas)
info.short_description: Index of primary care physician availability based on supply and demand of providers
info.long_description: Primary care availability based on 2-step enhanced floating catchment areas. This method is an aggregation of physicians per population ratios weighted by distance or travel time in each catchment area (area within which a provider is accessible). Weights are defined for the demand for physicians (population served by physicians). Provider address data were collected from WebMD's online Physician Directory.
info.statement: The primary care availability for {features.name} is {value}.
